RelationshipElement.description: Implements a 1:N relationship between Stone Artefact Clusters and Stone Associated Insitu

ArchaeologicalElement.name: Bone Associated Insitu Materials
ArchaeologicalElement.description: A material associated with a feature cluster

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_in_situ_material
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed in situ

lookup.term:
{hearthmaterial}

Hearthstones, baked sediment or charcoal/organic material

{mussel}

Mussel shell or shell fragment

{eggshell}

Emu, Genyornis or other eggshell

{stoneart}

Chipped, unmodified or ground stone

{otherwork}

Other worked or transported material

{good}

Majority of shell is whole or near whole, or articulated

{moderate}

Mixture of fragmented and near whole shell

{poor}

Majority of shell is highly fragmented

{yes}

Mussel is charred or calcined

{no}

none of the mussel is charred or calcined
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Hearth_Material
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{staining}

Sediment exhibits organic staining with or without charcoal
{other}

{hsclay}

Heat retainers made from clay or sandy clay

{hscarb}

Heat retainers made from carbonate nodules

{hsterm}

Heat retainers made from termite nest - sandy with visible voids and channels

{hsother}

Heat retainers made from other material, e.g. silcrete nodules (record in annotations)

{hsindet}

Too deeply buried or encrusted to determine type

{bakedclay}

Thin layer or small lumps of burnt clay, orange in colour when freshly exposed, broken surfaces may be smooth

{bakedsed}

Ashy sediment, baked hard

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Eggshell
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{emu}

Shell with 3-layered structure and orange-peel texture; texture disappears only when weathering reduces shell thickness to < 0.8mm

{genyo}

Shell with single layer, pores appear as short, parallel groove-like pin pricks

{other}

Other eggshell, clearly not emu or Genyornis

{indet}

Features unclear due to surface modification or shell is smooth and < 0.8mm thick

{yes}

Eggshell is charred or calcined

{no}

None of the eggshell is charred or calcined

{indet}

Cannot determine because material is embedded in sediment, covered with calcium carbonate or buried by a sand veneer

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Stone_Artefacts
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed

lookup.term: {indet}

{cs}

Chipped stone

{um}

Unmodified stone

{ground}

Ground stone

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Chipped_Stone_Artefacts
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{ru}

Retouched/utilised artefact

{co}

Core

{deb}

Flaking debris, including whole flakes, broken flakes and angular fragments

{hammer}

cobble with pitting or rounding on one or both ends

{indet}

Artefact too deeply buried or encrusted to determine type

{notch}

Retouch that creates one or more concavities along the margin of the tool

{scraper}

Flake (or other blank) with one or more margins of retouch

{backed}

Flake (or other blank) with one margin of steep, blunting retouch

{unifpt}

Retouch on one or more margins, which converges to a point in plan view, initiated from a single surface

{bifac}

Artefact with bifacial retouch i.e.retouch initiated alternatively from 2 opposed faces

{otherru}

Any other type of retouch or use-wear
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Unmodified_Stone
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{nodule}

A large, nodular or rounded cobble (>64 mm maximum dimension)

{slab}

A thick, flat piece of rock (>64 mm maximum dimension)

{pebble}

Small nodular or rounded piece, < 64 mm maximum dimension, unlikely to be useful for artefact manufacture
{all}
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Ground_Stone_Types_Present
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{millstone}

Large, concave to flattish ground surface

{muller}

Convex surface with facet from back and forth motion

{mortar}

A circular or oval basin

{pestle}

A cobble with convex or flattish ground end

{grooved}

Single or multiple grooves

{amorph}

Poorly defined, or small, discontinuous ground surface, not matching any of the above

{undiag}

Fragmentary, not complete enough to distinguish nature of ground surface
{indet}
{other}

property.name: OldBone_-_Ground_Stone_Status
property.description: Is the ground material...:

lookup.term:
{whole}

Artefact is intact

{fragment}

One or more fragments of a larger artefact or fragments of more than one artefact that do not refit

{refits}

Broken fragments can be refitted back together and/or texture, colour, thickness and/or surface modifications suggest that they are part of the same artefact

property.name: OldBone_-_Chipped_Stone_Raw_Material
property.description: Select those types of raw material that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{silcfine}

Quartz grains in the matrix are < 0.25 mm

{silcmed}

Quartz grains in the matrix are 0.25 -- 0.5 mm

{silccoarse}

Quartz grains in the matrix are greater than 0.5mm

{silcmicroxtal}

Naked eye cannot identify grains in the matrix

{qtzite}

Sugary texture, variable grain size and colour

{qtz}

A clear, white, milky white or rose coloured mineral

{other}

For example, carbonate (record in annotations)
{unident}
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Unmodified_Stone_Raw_Material
property.description: Select those types of raw material that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{silcfine}

Quartz grains in the matrix are < 0.25 mm
{unident}
{indet}

{silcmed}

Quartz grains in the matrix are 0.25 -- 0.5 mm

{silccoarse}

Quartz grains in the matrix are greater than 0.5mm

{silcmicroxtal}

Naked eye cannot identify grains in the matrix

{qtzite}

Sugary texture, variable grain size and colour

{qtz}

A clear, white, milky white or rose coloured mineral

{ironst}

Sedimentary rock containing iron-rich minerals

{sandst}

A clastic sedimentary rock made up of sand-sized minerals or grains

{other}

For example, carbonate (record in annotations)

property.name: OldBone_-_Ground_Stone_Raw_Material
property.description: Select those types of raw material that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{silcrete}

Quartz grains in the matrix are < 0.25 mm

{sandst}

Quartz grains in the matrix are 0.25 -- 0.5 mm

{qtzite}

Quartz grains in the matrix are greater than 0.5mm

{sandst}

A clastic sedimentary rock made up of sand-sized minerals or grains

{qtzite}

Sugary texture, variable grain size and colour

{ironst}

Sedimentary rock containing iron-rich minerals

{other}

For example, carbonate (record in annotations)
{unident}
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Associated_Other_Artefacts
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed:

lookup.term:
{bonemod}

Bone with a smoothed, ground surface which is pointed or bevelled at one or both ends; striations may be visible

{shellmod}

Thick fragment of shell with notches or other evidence of working or use along one or more margins

{eggmod}

Eggshell with modified surface, e.g. tooth mark or drill hole

{ochrediss}

Flecks or fragments of ochre disseminated through the sediment

{ochrenod}

Small nodule of ochre

{ochrefacet}

Ochre with facets, indicating use as crayon

{qtzxtal}

Worked or unworked quartz crystal

{turbo}

Marine gastropod up to 4cm long, with white zigzag stripes

{other}

Any other worked, utilised or transported material not listed above (record in annotations)

property.name: Hearth_-_Grid_Square
property.description: Letter code as marked in south-west corner of square

property.name: Hearth_-_ID_Number
property.description: Feature identification code as marked on tag

lookup.term:
{Hearths_with_heat-retainer_hearthstones}{hsterm}

Heat retainers made from termite nest - sandy with visible voids and channels

{hscarb}

Heat retainers made from carbonate nodules

{hsclay}

Heat retainers made from clay or sandy clay

{hsother}

Heat retainers made from other material, e.g. silcrete nodules (record in annotations)

{hsindet}

Too deeply buried or encrusted to determine type

{Hearths_without_hearthstones}{emupat}

Discrete patch of baked sediment resembling an emu (or cow) pat, usually containing ashy sediment and charcoal and/or organics

{bakedclay}

Thin, discrete layer of burnt clay (orange in colour, freshly broken surfaces may be smooth and lustrous) underlain by black stain, may or may not be associated with organic material

{bakedsed}

Any other patch of baked sediment, with or without associated charcoal or organic remains

{ashlens}

Discrete patch of ashy sediment with fragmented or disseminated charcoal and/or organics

{ashpatch}

a discrete patch of ashy sediment with fragmented or disseminated charcoal and/or organics

{charclens}

A discrete lens of charcoal fragments (rare)

{staining}

Black staining of the sediment that does not correspond to any of the above, no or very little charcoal present, no organic remains, undiffuse boundaries

{other}

A cluster of burnt material without clear hearth structure or sediment alteration, e.g. fish bone hearth, emu egg shell hearth (record in annotations)

property.name: Hearth_-_Brief_description
property.description: A few word description of an 'other' type of hearth or hearthstone, e.g. fish hearth, emu eggshell hearth, silcrete hearthstones

lookup.term:
{none}

No charcoal visible

{diss}

Disseminated charcoal: fine particles of charcoal dispersed through the hearth feature or its sedimentary matrix

{flecks}

Small fragments of charcoal dispersed through the hearth feature or its sedimentary matrix

{indet}

Dark particles or flecks visible, but origin indeterminate

{lumps}

Large lumps of charcoal within the hearth or its sedimentary matrix

property.name: Hearth_-_Proportion_of_material_that_remains_in_situ
property.description: Select the proportion of visible hearth material that remains in situ

lookup.term:
{most}

The mjaority of the visible hearth material is in situ

{some}

Some of the visible hearth material is in situ

{surface}

None of the hearth material is embedded in sediment

{recement}

The hearth material appears to be in situ but there is a high likelihood that it is actually cemented into redeposited sediment

{ambiguous}

The hearth material appears to be in situ but it is impossible to eliminate the possibility that it is recemented

property.name: Hearth_-_Modification_of_heat-retainer_hearths
property.description: Select the degree of post-exposure modification of the heat-retainer hearth:

lookup.term:
{fragdispers}

Hearth stones are broken up and widely dispersed from in situ or clustered hearthstones

{carb}

Surface is coverd with a deposit of calcium carbonate

{none}

Hearth structure is largely maintained, hearthstones are in good conditions

{frag}

Material highly fragmented

{dispers}

Material widely dispersed from in situ or clustered part of hearth
{polish}

{other}

Modification not described by any of the above (record in annotations)

property.name: Hearth_-_Modification_of_non-heat_retainer_hearths
property.description: Select the extent of post-exposure modification to non- heat retainer hearths:

lookup.term:
{none}

Hearth structure is intact and hearth material is largely unweathered

{fragdisp}

Components of the hearth are fragmented and dispersed
{other}

{weather}

Hearth material has started to weather and/or crumble, but the feature remains largely intact

{root}

roots or root channels running through the hearth

{incrill}

Incipient rill network extending to edge of hearth or cutting back into it

{rill}

Well-developed rills are cutting through the hearth

{undercut}

Underlying sediment has been removed through erosion

{gul}

Feature is bisected by an established gully

{frag}

Components of the hearth (eg. baked sediment, emu eggshell) are highly fragmented

property.name: Hearth_-_Topographic_Setting
property.description: Where on the lunette exposure is the hearth located?

lookup.term:
{platform}

Broad, flat platform exposure

{shalgulfl}

In the floor of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{shalgulwal}

In the wall of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{deepgulfl}

In the floor of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep

{deepgulwal}

In the wall of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep

{residtop}

Flat surface on top of a residual

{residside}

In the side of a residual

{chanfloor}

In the floor of a modern outwash channel

{chanwall}

In the wall of a modern outwash channel

{other}

topographic setting not described above, eg. Lake floor (record in annotations)

{less6Degree}

Slightly sloping surface

{6To12Degree}

Moderately sloping surface

{greater12Degree}

More steeply sloping surface

{shallrill}

Within a shallow rill

{rillfloor}

In the floor of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)

{rillwall}

In the wall of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)

{ridge}

On a narrow ridge in heavily eroded area

{ridgerill}

Feature in a heavily eroded area is cut by deep rills and straddles rill wall and rill flow

property.name: Hearth_-_Sediment_Type
property.description: What are the sediments that encase the hearth, or upon which they are immediately lying?

lookup.term:
{redsand}

quartz sand of a reddish colour

{pelletalclay}

grey clays made up of clay pellets

{alternat}

alternating beds of pelletal clay and quartz sand

{clay-alt}

distinct bed of pelletal clay within a sequence of alternating sands and clays

{sand-alt}

distinct bed of quartz sand within a sequence of alternating sands and clays

{bluelam-alt}

mm-thick, but laterally traceable lens of clay with distinct 'blue' colour

{greenclay}

clay of a green colour

{redsoil}

soil of a reddish colour

{brownsoil}

soil of a brownish colour

{darksoil}

soil with greyish to dark greyish colour, carbonate rich

{carbsoft}

sediment containing diffuse soil carbonate (C horizon)

{brownsand}

quartz sands of a brownish colour

{carbnodule}

sediment containing hard carbonate nodules (C horizon)

{carbpavemt}

well developed in situ soil carbonates forming a solid pavement

{carblag}

broken up, angular pieces of carbonate nodules, root traces, burrows, rhizomorphs representing a reworked lag

{finesilt}

fine, well-sorted silt with no clay component

{cobblebeach}

continuous bed of rounded carbonate nodules, rhizomorphs etc together with rounded pebbles/cobbles of qtz or rock fragments
{gravelbeach}
{other}

{whitesand}

sand that is clean (no clay) and white

{othersand}

quartz sands of a different colour (eg pink)

{clayeysand}

quartz sands that contain some clay

{laminarsand}

fine laminae of quartz sands, clayey sands and clays; brown colour, sands predominate

{redlamsand}

red sands preserving fine bedding

{unconsolsand}

unconsolidated sands, sometimes with thin horizons of carbonate (archaeology bearing)

{modernaeolian}

shifting veneer of unconsolidated sands or coppice sands
{Golgol}
{indet}
{other}
{ggC}
{gglag}

{allfan}

ancient alluvial fan

property.name: Hearth_-_Vulnerability_To_Erosion
property.description: Based on the cluster type and its topographic setting, how vulnerable is the hearth?

lookup.term:
{low}

On a relatively stable, flat surface or gentle slope that is not being eroded by rills, in well cemented (firm) sediment

{moderate}

Wider area is being eaten away by ongoing erosion, e.g. near edge of platform exposure, gully head, expanding rill system

{high}

High probability of material being removed by erosion, or of the hearth losing its integrity, e.g. relatively steep slope with incipient rills and/or in loose sandy sediment

{extreme}

Hearth material is in imminent danger of rapid removal and loss, e.g. edge of eroding residual or deep rill, in gully wall, on a steep slope- washed surface, or in loose sandy sediment

property.name: Hearth_-_Palaeotopographic_Setting
property.description: Where is the hearth cluster located in relation to the original dune morphology?

lookup.term:
{foredune}

Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the lakebed

{backdune}

Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the hinterland

{crest}

Crest of dune, stratigraphic layers slope away, towards both lakebed and hinterland

{beach}

An area of rounded cobbles or gravels in distinct horizon
{spit}

{lakebed}

Lakebed sediments

{indet}

Indeterminate
{other}

property.name: Hearth_-_Photos
property.description: Take 2 images: 1. landscape/stratigraphic setting (to aid re-location), include horizon and nearby landmarks that will have some longevity 2. the feature itself (to aid identification) -- include the critical components of the feature like the in situ portion of a hearth or bone cluster

property.name: Hearth_-_Notes
property.description: Any additional information worth noting that has not been covered by the recording

property.name: Shell_-_Grid_Square
property.description: Letter code as marked in south-west corner of square

property.name: Shell_-_ID_Number
property.description: Feature identification code as marked on tag

lookup.term:
{dispers}

Scattered shells eroding out across > 1metre of exposure, with no associated material, probably non-cultural in origin

{smallclust}

A discrete cluster containing a handful of mussel shells

{largeclust}

A large cluster of shells that extends for < 2 metres along a single horizon

{extthin}

A vertically constrained but laterally extensive cluster (or multiple discrete clusters) that extends > 2 metres along a single horizon
{extthick}

property.name: Shell_-_Continuity
property.description: Does it form a continuous blanket or is it patchy?

lookup.term:
{continuous}

A large or extensive cluster of mussel shells that forms a continuous deposit

{discontin}

Multiple clusters of mussel shell that probably formed a continuous deposit prior to erosion, or that represent the first exposure of a deposit that is likely to be continuous (e.g. in same stratigraphic layer)

property.name: Shell_-_Presence_of_charcoal
property.description: Select the type of charcoal visible in the shell midden

lookup.term:
{none}

No charcoal visible

{diss}

Disseminated charcoal: fine particles of charcoal dispersed through the hearth feature or its sedimentary matrix

{flecks}

Small fragments of charcoal dispersed through the hearth feature or its sedimentary matrix

{lumps}

Large lumps of charcoal within the hearth or its sedimentary matrix

{indet}

Dark particles or flecks visible, but origin indeterminate

property.name: Shell_-_Proportion_of_material_that_remains_in_situ
property.description: Select the proportion of visible shell material that remains in situ

lookup.term:
{most}

most of the visible shell is in situ

{some}

At least some of the shells are in in situ

{surface}

None of the shells are embedded in sediment

{recement}

Some shells appear to be in situ but there is a high likelihood that they have been cemented into redeposited sediment

{ambiguous}

The shells appear to be in situ but it is impossible to determine whether they are actually recemented

property.name: Shell_-_Bivalve_preservation
property.description: Select the degree of preservation of the shell material

lookup.term:
{good}

Majority of shell is whole or near whole, or articulated

{moderate}

Mixture of fragmented and near whole shell

{poor}

Majority of shell is highly fragmented

{low}

Surface scatter of material is confined to the area of in situ material, or, if only surface material is present, to a discrete, relatively dense, area

{moderate}

Some surface material is scattered beyond the in situ or dense area

{high}

Surface material is sparse and is scattered well beyond the in situ shells or dense clusters of surface shell

property.name: Shell_-_Topographic_Setting
property.description: Where on the lunette exposure is the object located?

lookup.term:
{platform}

Broad, flat platform exposure

{shalgulfl}

In the floor of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{shalgulwal}

In the wall of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{deepgulfl}

In the floor of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep

{deepgulwal}

In the wall of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep

{residtop}

Flat surface on top of a residual

{residside}

In the side of a residual

{chanfloor}

In the floor of a modern outwash channel

{chanwall}

In the wall of a modern outwash channel

{other}

topographic setting not described above, eg. Lake floor (record in annotations)

{less6Degree}

Slightly sloping surface

{6To12Degree}

Moderately sloping surface

{greater12Degree}

More steeply sloping surface

{shallrill}

Within a shallow rill

{rillfloor}

In the floor of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)

{rillwall}

In the wall of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)

{ridge}

On a narrow ridge in heavily eroded area

{ridgerill}

Feature in a heavily eroded area is cut by deep rills and straddles rill wall and rill flow

property.name: Shell_-_Sediment_Type
property.description: What are the sediments that encase the midden, or upon which they are immediately lying?

lookup.term:
{redsand}

quartz sand of a reddish colour

{pelletalclay}

grey clays made up of clay pellets

{alternat}

alternating beds of pelletal clay and quartz sand

{clay-alt}

distinct bed of pelletal clay within a sequence of alternating sands and clays

{sand-alt}

distinct bed of quartz sand within a sequence of alternating sands and clays

{bluelam-alt}

mm-thick, but laterally traceable lens of clay with distinct 'blue' colour

{greenclay}

clay of a green colour

{redsoil}

soil of a reddish colour

{brownsoil}

soil of a brownish colour

{darksoil}

soil with greyish to dark greyish colour, carbonate rich

sediment containing diffuse soil carbonate (C horizon)

{brownsand}

quartz sands of a brownish colour

{carbnodule}

sediment containing hard carbonate nodules (C horizon)

{carbpavemt}

well developed in situ soil carbonates forming a solid pavement

{carblag}

broken up, angular pieces of carbonate nodules, root traces, burrows, rhizomorphs representing a reworked lag

{finesilt}

fine, well-sorted silt with no clay component

{cobblebeach}

continuous bed of rounded carbonate nodules, rhizomorphs etc together with rounded pebbles/cobbles of qtz or rock fragments
{gravelbeach}
{other}

{whitesand}

sand that is clean (no clay) and white

{othersand}

quartz sands of a different colour (eg pink)

{clayeysand}

quartz sands that contain some clay

{laminarsand}

fine laminae of quartz sands, clayey sands and clays; brown colour, sands predominate

red sands preserving fine bedding

unconsolidated sands, sometimes with thin horizons of carbonate (archaeology bearing)

shifting veneer of unconsolidated sands or coppice sands

{other}

property.name: Shell_-_Vulnerability_To_Erosion
property.description: Based on the cluster type and its topographic setting, how vulnerable is the midden?

lookup.term:
{low}

On a relatively stable, flat surface or gentle slope that is not being eroded by rills, in well cemented (firm) sediment

{moderate}

Wider area is being eaten away by ongoing erosion, e.g. near edge of platform exposure, gully head, expanding rill system

{high}

High probability of material being removed by erosion, or of the hearth losing its integrity, e.g. relatively steep slope with incipient rills and/or in loose sandy sediment

{extreme}

Hearth material is in imminent danger of rapid removal and loss, e.g. edge of eroding residual or deep rill, in gully wall, on a steep slope- washed surface, or in loose sandy sediment

property.name: Shell_-_Palaeotopographic_Setting
property.description: Where is the object cluster located in relation to the original dune morphology?

lookup.term:
{allfan}

ancient alluvial fan

{indet}

Indeterminate

{foredune}

Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the lakebed

{backdune}

Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the hinterland

{crest}

Crest of dune, stratigraphic layers slope away, towards both lakebed and hinterland

{beach}

An area of rounded cobbles or gravels in distinct horizon
{spit}

{lakebed}

Lakebed sediments
{other}

property.name: HearthAssoc_-_Associated_terrestrial_bone

lookup.term:
{wombat}

Wombats have a distinctive morphology: broad flat skull, 2 incisors, no canine, molars that grow continuosly; they often died in their burrows, so are common in the record

{bettong}

Small burrowing marsupial with a distinctive, crested pre-molar, common in the record

{macropod}

Kangaroos (Western Grey, Eastern Grey, Red Kangaroo) and wallabies (e.g. hare-wallaby, nail-tail wallaby)

{smallmars}

Small marsupial other than bettong, for example, bandicoot, dasyurid, dunnart

{rodent}

Small mammal with distinctive incisors in upper & lower jaws

{emu}

most emu bones are heavy and solid in contrast to those of flying birds which are lightweight & hollow

{mammal}

characteristic of terrestrial mammal bone but more precise taxonomic identification not made

{birdbone}

bird other than emu; many bird bones are hollow, others have air pockets within semi-hollow bones

{reptile}

turtles, snakes and lizards

{other}

megafauna, amphibian, carnivore or a more precise taxonomic identification not listed above (record in annotations)

{unident}

potentially diagnostic features are present (articular ends, muscle markings, teeth, distinctive size/shape) but could not be identified by recorder

{undiag}

shape and size are not diagnostic of taxon and no other diagnostic features are preserved (teeth, muscle markings, articular ends)

none of the material is charred or calcined

Size/shape not diagnostic of taxon and no other diagnostic features preserved (articular ends, muscle markings, teeth)

megafauna, amphibian, echidna or a more prescise taxanomic identification not listed above (record in annotations)

{emu}

Most emu bones are heavy and solid in contrast to those of flying birds which are lightweight & hollow

{genyo}

Shell has a single layer; pores appear as short, parallel, groove-like pin pricks

property.name: Stone_-_Grid_Square
property.description: Letter code as marked in south-west corner of square

property.name: Stone_-_ID_Number
property.description: Artefact identification code as marked on tag

lookup.term: {Stone_artefacts_only}

{insitu}

2 or more in situ stone artefacts within 1 metre of each other, with no other associated material
{insit_oth}
{Stone_artefacts_and_other_material}

{surf}

Discrete cluster of artefacts of the same raw material, probably struck from the same core but no refits present, in a topographic and sedimentary context indicating that the artefacts could not have been transported
{surf_oth}

{both}

2 or more in situ stone artefacts within 1 metre of each other, plus a surface cluster of artefacts

{both_oth}

Both' in situ and surface artefacts (as defined above), associated with material other than stone artefacts, either in situ or on the surface

{surfrefit}

a collection of surface artefacts of the same raw material that contains 1 or more refits

property.name: Stone_-_In_Situ_-_Stone_Artefacts
property.description: In situ stone artefacts present

lookup.term: {indet}

{cs}

Chipped stone

{um}

Unmodified stone

{gs}

Ground stone

property.name: Stone_-_In_Situ_-_Chipped_Stone_Artefacts
property.description: In situ chipped stone artefacts present

lookup.term:
{ru}

Retouched/utilised artefact

{co}

Core

{deb}

Flaking debris, including whole flakes, broken flakes and angular fragments

{hammer}

cobble with pitting or rounding on one or both ends

{indet}

Artefact too deeply buried or encrusted to determine type

property.name: Stone_-_In_Situ_-_Retouched_Artefacts
property.description: In situ retouched artefacts present

lookup.term:
{notch}

Retouch that creates one or more concavities along the margin of the tool

{scraper}

Flake (or other blank) with one or more margins of retouch

{backed}

Flake (or other blank) with one margin of steep, blunting retouch

{unifpt}

Retouch on one or more margins, which converges to a point in plan view, initiated from a single surface

{bifacpt}

Artefact with bifacial retouch i.e.retouch initiated alternatively from 2 opposed faces

{otherru}

Any other type of retouch or use-wear
{unident}
{indet}

{nodule}

A large, nodular or rounded cobble (>64 mm maximum dimension)

{slab}

A thick, flat piece of rock (>64 mm maximum dimension)

{pebble}

Small nodular or rounded piece, < 64 mm maximum dimension, unlikely to be useful for artefact manufacture

{millstone}

Large, concave to flattish ground surface

{muller}

Convex surface with facet from back and forth motion

{mortar}

A circular or oval basin

{pestle}

A cobble with convex of flattish ground end

{grooved}

Single or multiple grooves

{amorph}

Poorly defined, or small, discontinuous ground surface, not matching any of the above

{undiag}

Fragmentary, not complete enough to distinguish nature of ground surface
{unident}
{other}

property.name: Stone_-_In_Situ_-_Ground_Stone_Status
property.description: Status of in situ ground stone artefacts

lookup.term:
{whole}

Artefact is intact

{fragmented}

One or more fragments of a larger artefact or fragments of more than one artefact that do not refit

{refit}

Broken fragments can be refitted back together and/or texture, colour, thickness and/or surface modifications suggest that they are part of the same artefact

property.name: Stone_-_In_Situ_-_Ground_Stone_Raw_Material
property.description: Raw materials for in situ ground stone artefacts

lookup.term:
{silcfine}

Quartz grains in the matrix are less than 0.25 mm

{silcmed}

Quartz grains in the matrix are 0.25 -- 0.5 mm

{silccoarse}

Quartz grains in the matrix are greater than 0.5mm

{silcmicroxtal}

Naked eye cannot identify grains in the matrix
{unident}

{sandst}

A clastic sedimentary rock made up of sand-sized minerals or grains

{qtzite}

Sugary texture, variable grain size and colour

{ironst}

Sedimentary rock containing iron-rich minerals

{other}

For example, carbonate (record in annotations)
{indet}

property.name: Stone_-_In_Situ_-_Surface_Modification
property.description: Surface modification on in situ artefacts

lookup.term:
{none}

Fresh, unaltered surfaces

{indet}

Artefact too deeply buried to determine modification

{algal}

A dense carbonate coating, often with a texture resembling cauliflower

{carb}

A thin or powdery coating of calcium carbonate

{abraded}

A scored or scratched surface and/or rounded and worn down flake scar ridges and margins

{polish}

Smoothed and glossy surface, flake scar ridges and margins may be muted
{other}

property.name: Stone_-_In_Situ_-_Potential_Refits
property.description: List the number of refits for each raw material, or the number of artefacts likely to have been struck from the same core.

property.name: Stone_-_Topographic_Setting
property.description: Where on the lunette exposure is the artefact cluster located?

lookup.term:
{platform}

Broad, flat platform exposure

{shalgulfl}

In the floor of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{shalgulwal}

In the wall of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{deepgulfl}

In the floor of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep

{deepgulwal}

In the wall of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep

{residtop}

Flat surface on top of a residual

{residside}

In the side of a residual

{chanfloor}

In the floor of a modern outwash channel

{chanwall}

In the wall of a modern outwash channel

{other}

topographic setting not described above, eg. Lake floor (record in annotations)

{less6Degree}

Slightly sloping surface

{6To12Degree}

Moderately sloping surface

{greater12Degree}

More steeply sloping surface

{shallrill}

Within a shallow rill

{rillfloor}

In the floor of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)

{rillwall}

In the wall of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)

{ridge}

On a narrow ridge in heavily eroded area

{ridgerill}

Feature in a heavily eroded area is cut by deep rills and straddles rill wall and rill flow

property.name: Stone_-_Sediment_Type
property.description: What are the sediments that encase the object, or upon which they are immediately lying?

lookup.term:
{redsand}

quartz sand of a reddish colour

{pelletalclay}

grey clays made up of clay pellets

{alternat}

alternating beds of pelletal clay and quartz sand

{clay-alt}

distinct bed of pelletal clay within a sequence of alternating sands and clays

{sand-alt}

distinct bed of quartz sand within a sequence of alternating sands and clays

{bluelam-alt}

mm-thick, but laterally traceable lens of clay with distinct 'blue' colour

{greenclay}

clay of a green colour

{redsoil}

soil of a reddish colour

{brownsoil}

soil of a brownish colour

{darksoil}

soil with greyish to dark greyish colour, carbonate rich

{carbsoft}

sediment containing diffuse soil carbonate (C horizon)

{brownsand}

quartz sands of a brownish colour

{carbnodule}

sediment containing hard carbonate nodules (C horizon)

{carbpavemt}

well developed in situ soil carbonates forming a solid pavement

{carblag}

broken up, angular pieces of carbonate nodules, root traces, burrows, rhizomorphs representing a reworked lag

{finesilt}

fine, well-sorted silt with no clay component

{cobblebeach}

continuous bed of rounded carbonate nodules, rhizomorphs etc together with rounded pebbles/cobbles of qtz or rock fragments
{gravelbeach}
{other}

{whitesand}

sand that is clean (no clay) and white

{othersand}

quartz sands of a different colour (eg pink)

{clayeysand}

quartz sands that contain some clay

{laminarsand}

fine laminae of quartz sands, clayey sands and clays; brown colour, sands predominate

{redlamsand}

red sands preserving fine bedding

{unconsolsand}

unconsolidated sands, sometimes with thin horizons of carbonate (archaeology bearing)

{modernaeolian}

shifting veneer of unconsolidated sands or coppice sands
{unident}
{Golgol}
{other}
{ggC}
{gglag}

property.name: Stone_-_Vulnerability_To_Erosion
property.description: Based on the cluster type and its topographic setting, how vulnerable is the object?

lookup.term:
{low}

On a relatively stable, flat surface or gentle slope that is not being eroded by rills, in well cemented (firm) sediment

{moderate}

Wider area is being eaten away by ongoing erosion, e.g. near edge of platform exposure, gully head, expanding rill system

{high}

High probability of material being removed by erosion, or of the hearth losing its integrity, e.g. relatively steep slope with incipient rills and/or in loose sandy sediment

{extreme}

Hearth material is in imminent danger of rapid removal and loss, e.g. edge of eroding residual or deep rill, in gully wall, on a steep slope- washed surface, or in loose sandy sediment

property.name: Stone_-_Palaeotopographic_Setting
property.description: Where is the object cluster located in relation to the original dune morphology?

lookup.term:
{allfan}

ancient alluvial fan

{foredune}

Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the lakebed

{backdune}

Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the hinterland

{crest}

Crest of dune, stratigraphic layers slope away, towards both lakebed and hinterland

{beach}

An area of rounded cobbles or gravels in distinct horizon
{spit}

{lakebed}

Lakebed sediments

{indet}

Indeterminate
{other}

property.name: Stone_-_Photos

property.name: Stone_-_Notes

{undiagbone}

Shape and size are not diagnostic of taxon and no other diagnostic features are preserved (teeth, muscle markings, articular ends)

{lacust}

Lacustrine material (including fish bone, otoliths, mussels)

{terrbone}

Terrestrial bone material

{eggshell}

Emu, Genyornis or other eggshell

Chipped, unmodified or ground stone

{otherwork}

Other worked or transported material

property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed

lookup.term:

Bony plate from the shell of a turtle

Both fish bone and otoliths present (if otoliths identified to taxon, record in annotations)

{fishbone}

Common taxa are Golden Perch, Silver Perch & Murray Cod but other taxa could be present; identified on basis of otoliths

{otoliths}

Fish ear bone, diagnostic of taxon; common taxa are Golden Perch, Silver Perch, Murray Cod (if identified, record in annotations)

{gastrolith}

Crustacean gastrolith

{exoskel}

Crustacean exoskeleton
{other}

{Yes}

Calcined or charred material present

{No}

none of the material is charred or calcined
{indet}

property.name: ShellAssoc_-_Associated_terrestrial_bone
property.description: If the bones of terrestrial animals are present in the midden, select which of those have been identified (refer to Bone module for more illustrations)

lookup.term:
{emu}

Most emu bones are heavy and solid in contrast to those of flying birds which are lightweight & hollow

{birdother}

Bird othe than emu; most bones are hollow, others are semi-hollow with air pockets

{mammal}

Record more detailed taxonomic information in annotations (eg. large or small macropod, bettong or other small marsupial, carnivore, rodent, mega-fauna)

{reptile}

Snakes and lizards (record in annotations); note that turtle is included with the lacustrine bone

{other}

Bones of other terrestrial animals not listed, e.g. amphibian (record in annotations)

{unident}

Potentially diagnostic features are present (articular ends, muscle markings, teeth, distinctive size/shape) but have not been identified by the recorder

{undiag}

Shape and size are not diagnostic of taxon and no other diagnostic features are preserved (teeth, muscle markings, articular ends)

property.name: ShellAssoc_-_Burnt_terrestrial_bone
property.description: Is any of it burnt?

lookup.term:
{Yes}

Calcined or charred material present

{No}

none of the material is charred or calcined

{indet}

Cannot determine because material is embedded in sediment, covered with other material or with a sand veneer

property.name: ShellAssoc_-_Associated_eggshell
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed

lookup.term:
{emu}

Shell has a 3-layered structure & orange-peel texture; texture disappears only when weathering reduces shell thickness to < 0.8mm

{genyo}

Shell has a single layer; pores appear as short, parallel, groove-like pin pricks

{other}

Other eggshell, clearly not emu or Genyornis (e.g. duck or swan)

{indet}

Features unclear due to surface modification or shell is smooth and < 0.8mm thick

property.name: ShellAssoc_-_Burnt_eggshell

{Yes}

none of the material is charred or calcined

Cannot determine because material is embedded in sediment, covered with other material or with a sand veneer

A large, nodular or rounded cobble (>64 mm maximum dimension)

{slab}

{pebble}

Sugary texture, variable grain size and colour

{ironst}

Sedimentary rock containing iron-rich minerals

property.name: OldBone_-_Grid_Square
property.description: Letter code as marked in south-west corner of square

property.name: OldBone_-_ID_Number
property.description: Feature identification code as marked on tag

lookup.term:
{boneOnly}{insitBO}

2 or more in situ elements, a set of in situ articulated elements, or an in situ skeleton, not associated with any other in situ or surface material

{surfBO}

discrete cluster of bones of a similar type (part of same element or same skeleton, or in a similar state of preservation) on the surface, but in a topographic and sedimentary context indicating that they have not been transported

{insitAndSurf}

2 or more in situ elements, a set of in situ articulated elements, or an in situ skeleton, plus a discrete surface cluster of bones of a similar type
{boneAndOtherMaterial}{inistAndOth}{surfAndOth}{bothAndOth}

property.name: OldBone_-_Proportion_of_material_that_remains_in_situ
property.description: Select the proportion of visible bone that remains insitu

lookup.term:
{most}

the majority of the visible bone is in situ

{some}

at least some of the bone is in situ

{surface}

no bone is embedded in sediment

{recement}

the bone appears to be in situ, but there is a high likelihood that it is actually cemented in redeposited sediment

{ambiguous}

the bone appears to be in situ, but it is impossible to say whether it is actually recemented

property.name: OldBone_-_Body_Parts_Identifed
property.description: Select those of the following that have been observed, both in situ and on the surface

lookup.term:
{cranAndTooth}

cranial elements, including maxilla with teeth

{exoskel}

exoskeleton

{scute}

bony plate from the shell of a turtle
{other}

{unident}

potentially diagnostic features are present (articular ends, muscle markings, teeth, distinctive size/shape) but have not been identified by the recorder

{undiag}

shape and size are not diagnostic of body part and no other diagnostic features are preserved (teeth, muscle markings, articular ends)

{cranNoTooth}

cranial elements (with or without maxilla) but no teeth

{mandAndteeth}

lower jaw, with teeth

{mandNoteeth}

lower jaw without teeth

{limb}

limb bones including scapula (shoulder), humerus (upper arm), radius/ulna (lower arm), wrist, hand & finger bones, femur (thigh), tibia/fibula (lower leg), ankle, heel, foot & toe bones

{axial}

axial elements: vertebrae, sternum and ribs

{allparts}

some elements of each of cranial, limb and axial bones

{otoliths}

fish ear bone, diagnostic of taxon; common taxa are Golden Perch, Silver Perch, Murray Cod (if identified, record in annotations)

{glith}

gastroliths

property.name: OldBone_-_Taxon_Identified
property.description: Select those of the following that can be identified:

lookup.term:
{wombat}

wombats have a distinctive morphology: broad flat skull, 2 incisors, no canine, molars that grow continuosly; they often died in their burrows, so are common in the record

{emu}

most emu bones are heavy and solid in contrast to those of flying birds which are lightweight & hollow

{birdother}

bird other than emu; many bird bones are hollow, others have air pockets within semi-hollow bones

{fish}

common taxa are Golden Perch, Silver Perch & Murray Cod but other taxa could be present; identified on basis of otoliths (record in annotations)

{crustac}

crustacean including freshwater crayfish

{other}

amphibian, echidna or a more precise taxonomic identification not listed above (record in annotations)

{unident}

potentially diagnostic features are present (articular ends, muscle markings, teeth, distinctive size/shape) but have not been identified by the recorder

{undiag}

shape and size are not diagnostic of taxon and no other diagnostic features are preserved (teeth, muscle markings, articular ends)

{bettong}

small burrowing marsupial with a distinctive, crested pre-molar, common in the record

{macropod}

kangaroos (Western Grey, Eastern Grey, Red Kangaroo) and wallabies (e.g. hare-wallaby, nail-tail wallaby)

{smallmars}

small marsupial (other than bettong), for example, bandicoot, dasyurid, dunnart

{carnivore}

carnivores have long, sharp teeth designed for ripping, tearing or cutting flesh, for example, Thylacine (Tasmanian tiger), Sarcophilus (Tasmanian Devil)

{rodent}

small mammal with distinctive incisors in upper & lower jaws

{mega}

remains of megafauna, recognized on basis of large size compared to extant relatives

{mammal}

characteristic of terrestrial mammal bone but more precise taxonomic identification not made

{reptile}

turtles, snakes and lizards

property.name: OldBone_-_Bone_Preservation
property.description: Select those types of modification that are common on the visible bone:

lookup.term:
{good}

surface of the bone appears fresh and unaltered

{polish}

smoothed surface with glossy appearance

{abraded}

scored or scratched surface, muted, rounded edges and/or muscle markings
{indet}
{other}

{orgstain}

brownish staining (of varying intensity) from contact with decaying plant and animal matter when buried

{minstain}

flecks of manganese or other dark minerals

{soft}

bone is soft and friable

{carb}

carbonate encrustation on surface of bone

{weathpost}

post exposure bleaching, cracking, splitting of bone

{weathpre}

pre-burial cracking, splitting or corrosioin of bone as a result of sub-aerial weathering

{fragpost}

post-exposure fragmentation and splintering of bone

{fragpre}

evidence for breakage prior to fossilisation

property.name: OldBone_-_Deliberate_Surface_Modification
property.description: Select those types of deliberate modification that occur in any proportion on the visible bone:

lookup.term:
{none}

surfaces appear fresh and unaltered

{toothmarks}

puncture or gnaw marks left by carnivores, snakes or rodents

{burned}

charred or calcined

{cutmarks}

fine grooves running across the organic structures that may have been made by stone tools

{impact}

impact feature, flake scar or flake resulting from hammerstone impact
{other}
{indet}

property.name: OldBone_-_Topographic_Setting
property.description: Where on the lunette exposure is the old bone located?

lookup.term:
{platform}

broad, flat platform exposure

{shalgulfl}

in the floor of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{shalgulwal}

in the wall of a gully less than 1.5m wide or deep

{deepgulfl}

in the floor of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep

{deepgulwal}

in the wall of a gully greater than 1.5m wide and deep

{residtop}

flat surface on top of a residual

{residside}

in the side of a residual

{chanfloor}

in the floor of a modern outwash channel

{chanwall}

in the wall of a modern outwash channel

{other}

topographic setting not described above, eg. Lake floor (record in annotations)

{less6Degree}

slightly sloping surface

{6To12Degree}

moderately sloping surface

{greater12Degree}

more steeply sloping surface

{shallrill}

within a shallow rill

{rillfloor}

in the floor of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)

{rillwall}

in the wall of a deep rill (strong, vertical rilling in clay-rich sediments)

{ridge}

on a narrow ridge in heavily eroded area

{ridgerill}

feature in a heavily eroded area is cut by deep rills and straddles rill wall and rill flow

property.name: OldBone_-_Sediment_Type
property.description: What are the sediments that encase the old bone, or upon which they are immediately lying?

lookup.term:
{redsand}

quartz sand of a reddish colour

{pelletalclay}

grey clays made up of clay pellets

{alternat}

alternating beds of pelletal clay and quartz sand

{clay-alt}

distinct bed of pelletal clay within a sequence of alternating sands and clays

{sand-alt}

distinct bed of quartz sand within a sequence of alternating sands and clays

{bluelam-alt}

mm-thick, but laterally traceable lens of clay with distinct 'blue' colour

{greenclay}

clay of a green colour

{redsoil}

soil of a reddish colour

{brownsoil}

soil of a brownish colour

{darksoil}

soil with greyish to dark greyish colour, carbonate rich

{carbsoft}

sediment containing diffuse soil carbonate (C horizon)

{brownsand}

quartz sands of a brownish colour

{carbnodule}

sediment containing hard carbonate nodules (C horizon)

{carbpavemt}

well developed in situ soil carbonates forming a solid pavement

{carblag}

broken up, angular pieces of carbonate nodules, root traces, burrows, rhizomorphs representing a reworked lag

{finesilt}

fine, well-sorted silt with no clay component

{cobblebeach}

continuous bed of rounded carbonate nodules, rhizomorphs etc together with rounded pebbles/cobbles of qtz or rock fragments
{gravelbeach}
{other}

{whitesand}

sand that is clean (no clay) and white

{othersand}

quartz sands of a different colour (eg pink)

{clayeysand}

quartz sands that contain some clay

{laminarsand}

fine laminae of quartz sands, clayey sands and clays; brown colour, sands predominate

{redlamsand}

red sands preserving fine bedding

{unconsolsand}

unconsolidated sands, sometimes with thin horizons of carbonate (archaeology bearing)

{modernaeolian}

shifting veneer of unconsolidated sands or coppice sands
{Golgol}
{other}
{indet}
{ggC}
{gglag}

property.name: OldBone_-_Vulnerability_To_Erosion
property.description: Based on the cluster type and its topographic setting, how vulnerable is the old bone?

lookup.term:
{low}

on a relatively stable, flat surface or gentle slope that is not being eroded by rills, in well cemented (firm) sediment

{moderate}

wider area is being eaten away by ongoing erosion, e.g. near edge of platform exposure, gully head, expanding rill system

{high}

high probability of material being removed by erosion, or of the hearth losing its integrity, e.g. relatively steep slope with incipient rills and/or in loose sandy sediment

{extreme}

hearth material is in imminent danger of rapid removal and loss, e.g. edge of eroding residual or deep rill, in gully wall, on a steep slope- washed surface, or in loose sandy sediment

property.name: OldBone_-_Palaeotopographic_Setting
property.description: Where is the old bone cluster located in relation to the original dune morphology?

lookup.term:
{foredune}

stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the lakebed

{backdune}

Stratigraphic layers are sloping towards the hinterland

{crest}

Crest of dune, stratigraphic layers slope away, towards both lakebed and hinterland

{beach}

An area of rounded cobbles or gravels in distinct horizon
{spit}

{allfan}

ancient alluvial fan

{lakebed}

Lakebed sediments
{other}

{indet}

Indeterminate
